item.title: Whistling Sling Bullets Were Roman Troops' Secret Weapon

media:content.media:description: Sling bullets and stones are a common find at Roman army battle sites in Europe. The largest are typically shaped like lemons and weigh up to 2 ounces (60 grams).
media:content.media:credit: Peter van der Sluijs via Wikimedia Commons CC by 3.0 Unported

item.dc:creator: Tom Metcalfe
LiveScience
item.description:
Soldiers 1,500 years ago used drilled projectiles to intimidate enemies with a shrill, buzzing sound

-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com

item.title: Is Particle Physics About to Crack Wide Open?

media:content.media:description: ATLAS particle detector at the Large Hadron Collider, near Geneva
media:content.media:credit: CERN via Flickr under Creative Commons license

item.dc:creator: Michele Redi
item.description:
Hints of an unexpected new particle could be confirmed within days—and if it is, the Standard Model could be going down

-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com

item.title: Go to the (White) Light
item.dc:creator: Christopher Intagliata
item.description:
An energy-efficient alternative to LEDs has greater focusing power, for microscopes and spotlights. Christopher Intagliata reports.

item.title: Google Moves Closer to a Universal Quantum Computer

media:content.media:description: Corporate headquarters complex of Google in Mountain View, California.
media:content.media:credit: Brooks Kraft LLC/Corbis via Getty Images

item.dc:creator: Philip Ball
Nature magazine
item.description:
Combining the best of analog and digital approaches could yield a full-scale multipurpose quantum computer

item.title: The Documentary Fastball Tosses Some Physics at Fans

item.description:
A movie about baseball's primary pitch is a hit

item.title: LISA Pathfinder Reports Record-Breaking Gravitational Wave Results

media:content.media:description: Artist’s impression of the European Space Agency’s LISA Pathfinder spacecraft, a technological testbed for future space-based gravitational-wave observatories.

item.dc:creator: Lee Billings
item.description:
The successful technology demonstration paves the way for detecting mergers of supermassive black holes with future space-based observatories

-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com

item.title: The Universe May Be Expanding Faster Than Astronomers Thought

media:content.media:description: Hubble Space Telescope view of the galaxy UGC 9391, which contains Cepheid variable stars and supernovas that scientists studied to calculate a newly precise value for Hubble's constant.

item.dc:creator: Mike Wall
SPACE.com
item.description:
“Dark radiation” is named as a possible factor, as a new study suggests expansion could be 9 percent faster

-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com

item.title: Can You Spot the Dot?

media:content.media:description: The amazing disappearing dot! It's not magic--it's science! Learn how you can fool your own eyes with this suprising science activity.

item.dc:creator: Science Buddies
item.description:
A ColorFULL activity from Science Buddies

item.title: How Mistakes Help Science [Video]
item.dc:creator: Clara Moskowitz
item.description:
Astrophysicist Mario Livio will discuss how famous thinkers’ blunders have played a vital role in research during a live Webcast tonight at 7 P.M.

-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com

item.title: Why It's Okay to Teach Wrong Ideas in Physics

media:content.media:description: Niels Bohr's original (incorrect) model of the atom.

item.dc:creator: Sam Anderson
item.description:
The story of how Niels Bohr got the structure of the atom wrong, and how that was corrected, tells us a lot about how science works

-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com

item.title: For Asteroid-Hunting Astronomers, Nathan Myhrvold Says the Sky Is Falling

media:content.media:description: A new study from the wealthy technologist Nathan Myhrvold casts doubt on data from an asteroid-hunting NASA mission, suggesting that astronomers are in the dark about the magnitude of threats posed by potentially hazardous space rocks.

item.dc:creator: Lee Billings
item.description:
The wealthy technologist claims some of the world’s top experts on Earth-threatening asteroids are guilty of bad science

-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com

item.title: Bigger Is Better for Neutrino Astronomy

media:content.media:description: The giant IceCube neutrino detector sprawls across a cubic kilometer of pristine ice in Antarctica, but it could be dwarfed by the neutrino telescopes of the future.

item.dc:creator: Spencer Klein
Nature magazine
item.description:
To glimpse particles from the most energetic events in the universe, astronomers must build truly gigantic detectors

-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com

item.title: Has a Hungarian Physics Lab Found a Fifth Force of Nature?
item.dc:creator: Edwin Cartlidge
Nature magazine
item.description:
Some theorists say a radioactive decay anomaly could imply a fundamental new force

item.title: Giant Tsunami Remnants Spotted on Mars
item.dc:creator: Lee Billings
item.description:
Evidence indicates that waves as tall as skyscrapers and thousands of kilometers wide once washed over the Red Planet.

item.title: Hunt for Big Bang Gravitational Waves Gets $40-Million Boost

media:content.media:description: The Simons Observatory will search for gravitational waves in the cosmic microwave background, using telescopes based on the technology of current projects such as the Atacama Cosmology Telescope, pictured here, in Chile.

item.dc:creator: Clara Moskowitz
item.description:
The nonprofit Simons Foundation will fund a new observatory to search for signs of stretching in the very early universe

-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
